newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - November 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - November 1.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for Reuters by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi. Tel:3326806, 3326813, 3326849 Fax:+91-11-3351006 E-mail:
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
TOP STORIES
The Pioneer
FORMER PRIME MINISTER'S ARREST LIKELY

Former minister and the prime accused in the 35 million rupee political payoff case, Satish Sharma, was interrogated after his arrival from the Netherlands. Sharma was questioned about nearly 20 million rupees which he had allegedly arranged from industrial houses for payment to four Opposition members of parliament for their support against the no-confidence motion. Meanwhile, the arrest of former prime minister Narasimha Rao, Sharma and former minister Buta Singh is likely. Officers of the Central Bureau of Investigation said non-bailable warrants against the three would be filed immediately to pre-empt any moves by the accused to obtain anticipatory bail from a higher court.
The Economic Times
FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS TO ALLY WITH BAT

Senior directors of financial institutions (FIs) went into a huddle to work out the course of action for their nominees on the ITC board, following the enforcement directorate's crackdown on the tobacco major. Sources said FIs were considering a joint course of action in collaboration with B.A.T Industries, the single largest shareholder in ITC. Sources said B.A.T might also send its representatives to the country to monitor the situation.
CABINET PANEL TO REVISE CORE SECTOR POLICIES

The Cabinet Committee on Infrastructure has decided to review policies in the oil, coal, transport (railways, civil aviation and surface transport), power and telecommunication sectors. Official sources said priority would be given to roads, for which a new policy on private sector investment would be cleared shortly. Sources also said as a part of quick clearances for fast track power projects, the Hinduja's National Power project in Andhra Pradesh would be the next project to be granted cabinet-level clearances.
BAJAJ AUTO FIRST-HALF NET PROFIT UP 27 PCT

Two wheeler manufacturer Bajaj Auto declared a net profit of over 2.25 billion rupees for the six month period ending September 30, 1996, up by 27 percent over the corresponding period in 1995. The increase in profit pushed the share price of the company by 15 rupees over its previous closing to end at 260 rupees. Gross profit showed an increase of 30 percent from 3.07 billion to 4 billion rupee. The company aims to reach a capacity of two million vehicles by the end of 1999. Production is expected to reach that level by the end of the year 2000 meeting international emission standards.
MAHINDRA NETS 920 MILLION RUPEES IN FIRST HALF

Utility vehicle and truck manufacturer, Mahindra and Mahindra (M&M), notched up net profits of 924.3 million rupees in the first six months (April-September) of 1996/97. It recorded a 738.1 million rupee net in the corresponding period of the previous fiscal, a rise of 25 percent. The total income, net of excise duty, increased to 14.67 billion rupees as against 11.33 billion in the previous year, a rise of 23 percent. Profit before tax increased 12 percent to 1.38 billion rupees, as against 1.23 billion in the previous fiscal. Production of vehicles increased 15 percent to 34,809 while sales, including exports, increased by 16 percent to 35,454 during the period.
INDUSTRY MINISTER CLEARS 63 PROPOSALS

The Industry Minister cleared 63 proposals recommended by the Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB), amounting to 24.28 billion rupees foreign direct investment (FDI). The approvals include RPG Telephone's proposal for 48 percent foreign equity worth five billion rupees. Other proposals to be approved include Gillette's 49 percent foreign investment ($60 million) for shaving blades and Cadbury Schweppes $15 million wholly-owned subsidiary. Harris Corp's wholly owned subsidiary for telecommunication equipment and Electricite de France's 51 percent investment for operation and maintenance services for thermal power stations were also approved, among others.
BHEL, SIEMENS IN POWER PLANT VENTURE

Leading power equipment, engineering and manufacturing company, Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd (BHEL), has joined hands with German multinational Siemens AG. The two would set up a 50:50 joint venture company in India for carrying out plant performance improvement of old fossil fuel power plants. BHEL sources said the proposed joint venture would strengthen the close cooperation existing between the two companies for more than two decades in the power equipment field.
Financial Express
TATA TELESERVICES TO INVEST 65 BILLION RUPEES IN 15 YEARS

Tata-Bell Canada combine Tata Teleservices, which bagged the basic telecommunication services licence for the Andhra Pradesh circle, will invest over 65 billion rupees over the next 15 years in the state. This is in addition to the 42 billion rupee licence fee. The other Tata-Bell Canada combine, Tata Communications, which is setting up the cellular network in the state, will invest over 6.7 billion rupees in addition to the 10 billion rupee license fees.
FORMER ITC CHIEFS ARRESTED

Former ITC chairmen J.N. Sapru and K.L. Chugh were taken into custody following their interrogation by the Enforcement Directorate (ED). They were interrogated in connection with a $100 million foreign exchange regulation violation. Sapru and Chugh are likely to be booked for diverting $4 million from ITC's tobacco division export proceeds to Swiss bank accounts. Both Sapru and Chugh have denied their involvement in the transactions which violated foreign exchange laws.
CABINET CLEARS IPCL, VIDEOCON POWER, SKYCELL PROJECTS

The Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs (CCEA) and the Cabinet Committee on Foreign Investment (CCFI) cleared a number of proposals. CCEA approved incremental capital investment of 4.62 billion rupees for Dipka expansion project of South Eastern Coalfields. CCFI gave accordance to Videocon Power, FASCEL, Skycell Communications and Microwave Communications' proposals for either raising foreign equity or equity amount. The cabinet also approved the Indian Petrochemicals Corporation's proposal to raise $175 million in the international market.
The Observer
INDUSTRIAL GROWTH RATE DROPS TO 8.9 PCT

The overall industrial growth registered by 172 industries remained at a low of 8.9 percent during April-July this year. Industry ministry figures show these industries, accounting for 88 percent of the index of industrial production, had registered a 12 percent plus growth rate in the corresponding period last year. Industries which recorded an impressive growth rate include cement (13.6 percent), pig iron (15.5 percent), aluminium extruded products (20.4 percent), motor cycles (26.6 percent), cars (23.7 percent), scooters (22.8 percent), chemical and pharmaceutical machinery (27 percent) and power-driven pumps (27.6 percent).
DIVESTMENT PANEL TO GIVE RECAST OPTION TO 40 FIRMS

The Disinvestment Commission has decided to give a restructuring option to the 40 public sector undertakings (PSUs), shortlisted for disinvestment. Commission chairman G.V. Ramakrishnan said if the PSUs failed to come up with a restructuring plan, then their shares would be put up for sale. The commission would not be involved in the disinvestment of equity of any of the public sector undertakings in the current fiscal 1996/97 (April-March), he added.
SERVICE-TAX IMPOSED; DRAWBACK RULES RELAXED

To enhance earnings in fiscal 1996/97 (April-March), the Finance Ministry has imposed a five percent service tax on advertising, radio paging and courier services. It has also made some amendments in the Customs and Central Excise Duties Drawback Rules of 1995. The ministry has simplified the procedure for disbursements of drawback to make faster payment of drawback. In the interest of export promotion, it has reduced the number of documents needed to be produced by the exporter. Official sources said exporters would not have to file a separate claim in customs for getting drawback.
Business Line
SIEMENS PLANNING 47 BILLION RUPEE INVESTMENT

German multinational Siemens AG plans to invest approximately 23.5 billion to 47 billion rupees in the next five years in sectors as diverse as infrastructure and consumer goods. Even though the company was interested in investing in India, Siemens expressed unhappiness over the problems they suffered at their telecommunication unit near Calcutta. Despite problems in the telecommunication sector, the company would not withdraw from India or the telecommunication sector. Siemens was also keen to invest in build-operate-transfer power projects.
